abstract_summ: COVID-19 is among a family of viruses-called coronaviruses-that can affect both humans and animals (Zhu et al., 2020).A novel coronavirus, probably of bat origin, has caused an outbreak of severe respiratory infection in humans in Wuhan, China and has been dispersed globally by travelers.I am now summarizing the research literature published between end of February to mid‐April 2020.After reading the article speculating that novel coronavirus from Wuhan may be transmitted to humans through snakes, I think the most critical analysis method is synonymous codon usage analysis, which estimated the relative synonymous codon usage (RSCU) of the 2019‐nCoV and its potential hosts.The data shown are specific to the four studied coronaviruses, and may or may not generalize to Covid-19.An epidemic of a novel coronavirus emerged from Wuhan, China, in late December 2019 and has since spread to several large Chinese cities.A novel coronavirus has caused thousands of human infections in China since December 2019, raising a global public health concern.Another animal to human transmission of a coronavirus occurred in December 2019 on a live animal market in the Chinese city of Wuhan causing an epidemic in China, reaching now different continents.
title_summ: Unveiling the Origin and Transmission of 2019-nCoVThe Novel Coronavirus – A Snapshot of Current KnowledgeSeasonality of Coronavirus 229E, HKU1, NL63 and OC43 from 2014-2020Potential for global spread of a novel coronavirus from ChinaThe Novel Coronavirus – Latest FindingsComments on "Cross‐species transmission of the newly identified coronavirus 2019‐nCoV"Nursing and the novel coronavirus:Risks and responsibilities in a global outbreakTravellers give wings to novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV)Novel coronavirus: From discovery to clinical diagnostics
